ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- transition metal chemistry, mainly coordination chemistry
- applications of symmetry to chemical reactivity
atomic/molecular/coordination structure, crystal/ligand field theory, symmetry of molecules, inorganic reactions, quantum microstates, coordination chemistry,

I learned absolutely nothing in lecture. 

In discussion section and peer tutor office hours I learned some mathematical and theoretical approaches to inorganic chemistry. Symmetry groups and characterization of molecules, coordination chemistry and their specific electronic configurations that give rise to unique chemical characteristics, and more advanced forms of acid/base chemistry useful for interpretation of reactions and reaction mechanisms in inorganic contexts.
I learned about different concepts relating to inorganic chemistry, such as crystal structure, coordination complexes, organometallic chemistry, etc.
Chemistry of Metals, Bonding, Group theory, reactivity. Inorganic chemistry with a special emphasis of Prof. Wang's research group.

This course was a decent introduction to the field of inorganic chemistry. I learned about a lot of topics that underly the subject in a pretty interesting way. I learned how to actually read a textbook to survive in a class.

I gained a good overview of inorganic chemistry concepts and how to apply these to applicable areas. I think this was good exposure to see that there are many different ways of studying chemistry besides the approach in O Chem. Inorganic is more rigorous and conducted more mathematically, which I enjoyed a lot.

I liked the structure of this course. I learned a lot about inorganic chemistry and it made me realize why I enjoy chemistry (as my other chemistry class CHEM 221 was very disorganized and was very discouraging)
I gained a solid foundation in many concepts that fall under inorganic chemistry.

We learned about how symmetry analysis can be applied to molecules to understand reactivity and structure. We spent a lot of time learning how to construct molecular orbital diagrams for substances, how atomic trends inform orbital energies and reactivity, different kinds of inorganic reactions, and how different kinds of inorganic laboratory techniques (e.g. IR/Raman spectroscopy) can be used to learn about inorganic structures.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strength: follows the textbook reasonably well, fast grading
weaknesses: lecture slides a bit too sparse, harsh grading (lack of partial credit), midterm keys not made available

Professor Wang, despite being an incredible researcher, is not a good lecturer. His slides were screenshots of the textbook, and he did a poor job of defining concepts straight from the beginning. I think having a clear foundation from the start of each unit would have been helpful, but the lack of it made class confusing. Elisabeth and Madison (our peer tutor) did the best they could to fill in the gaps.

The materials follow the textbook really closely, so the up side is that there's not too many surprises while the downside is that I just learned the entire thing from textbook instead of lecture. I think the lecture doesn't have enough time to cover the material as in depth as the book, so it gets confusing with just lecture sometimes. You must read the textbook.
I did not feel that the exams were reflective of my understanding of the material.

This course could have just been called "Tables from the Inorganic Chemistry Textbook". Lecture slides were nothing more than screenshots taken directly from the textbook that were too loosely explained to be applied to context in problem sets and on exams. Little to no useful resources for exam preparation were provided and communication from the instructor was extremely lacking. There seemed to be no obvious structure to the course and no logical progression of topics addressed. Examples introduced in class were usually not explained, covered in loose detail, never referenced by name, and were always accompanied with a rationalization that due to the presence of the explanation of the concept in the textbook, no further detail or explanation of the topic in question was needed for further understanding. When concepts were not chocked up to their presence in the textbook, the explanation that accompanied them was plain wrong and later cleared up when questions probing the validity of the professor's statements arose. No feedback was written on exam questions guiding to the reasoning behind losing points nor the correct approach and answer to the problems. Long problem sets were given on the same weeks as exams which caused frantic behavior and unnecessary anxiety in students who were all left with little time to study appropriately for the exam.

Below I have included an excerpt of a transcripted lecture of an attempted explanation for using a Tanabe Sugano diagram to determine quantitative measures of spectroscopic d electron transitions in transition metal complexes for your reference:
So so what is this about, oh this is about a vanadium complex transition 

So what do you do in the first step pull up TS diagram 

D2 so then you see the ground state and excited state so you have three options but you only see two peaks so what is going on? *blank stare* the peak is not shown bc its high energy one that is not captured 

If you know the energy of that and you know the energy of that then how to determine the that? Then you see that the energy transitions is higher and from this one to this one so so you think about that 

And then this one does not qualify to give you this transition so the only option is the second one, the first transition energy and the second transition energy are not exactly the same so then if you use that to find the position where your complex is at

You can get this information from the diagram, when this field is low 1st low second high then ration will decrease decrease decrease decrease and then its bout 30 but then when you know the position about 30 then you can measure the next level which is about 40 and then you can find B 

This example is from the textbook so you can read more about it. 

And this is it for today so see you next week.

You will need to read the textbook to do well in the class. Lectures do not always cover all the necessary information (or its just not explained well). The exams were often nothing like the problem sets, and there was very little support offered to prepare for them. The practice tests we received were the tests the previous instructor used, but these tests were not the same format as the tests in this course nor did they always focus the same exact concepts. The TF and peer tutor for this course were amazing and very helpful.
The biggest strength of this class was its rigor. It was quite demanding and really forced me to know the material inside and out.

Strengths: I think the two main strengths of this course were the peer tutor, Madison, and the TA, Elisabeth. The two of them were pretty much everyone's saving grace throughout the course. They were very compassionate with struggling students, and tried to make them interested in inorganic chemistry.
Weaknesses: I think Prof. Wang's teaching style was the main weakness of this class. Any class that can essentially be survived by just reading the textbook and not coming to class has some major weaknesses, and this was one of them. Often times, the professor would skip over challenging examples to "let us figure it out in the textbook," which made homework very challenging. I also didn't love that there was three exams with no drops, and that the final was worth a heavy portion of our grade. Essentially, that meant that most of your grade was from four exams.

Strengths: interesting content, fair exams, comprehensive textbook

Weaknesses: the content can be pretty confusing at times and I think the teaching was only sometimes good at alleviating this confusion, the professor and TF did not always seem the most invested
I liked this course.

Strengths of this course included the interesting material, relevant problem sets, and abundance of support from the professor, TF, and peer tutor. A weakness of this course was the lack of off-textbook teaching; I would have liked to have seen alternative explanations, figures, and examples in lectures that could not be found in the textbook.

I think the course covered a lot of ground. This is good because it was a useful introduction to inorganic chemistry, building from atomic trends to more complicated reactions and organometallics. A weakness, however, was that a lot of the important things were minimally addressed in lecture and a lot of weight was left on students to read the entire book and answer their own questions. When we're moving at roughly a chapter a week, this becomes difficult and nearly impossible if you're not giving the class a lot of attention. The lectures were essentially copied from the book and, while as an effort to cover less every week than was in the book (though the things not in lecture were still tested on), many important things were discussed quickly and things spiraled into a lot of confusion. Perhaps this could be improved if the course material was a little more diluted and things had the time they needed when taught. This could be accomplished by limited some of the discussions at the beginning of the course (orbital structures, atomic trends, etc.) that, with the prerequisites in mind, should be well understood.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Depends on the professor. If you learn well through a textbook, then Professor Wang is great. But if you prefer a little more into relevant research topics and lab-applicable lessons, then Professor Holland is better.

Most people who take this course do so because it's required by the chemistry major. I wouldn't recommend for non-chem majors but if transition metal chemistry is particularly relevant for your research / you found such topics in gen chem really interesting, then I guess you could take inorganic chemistry. It definitely requires a lot of self-study via the textbook.
Yes. It's a completely different field of chemistry compared to orgo and pchem, and is definitely worth learning about to understand metal chemistry and more structural based analyses.
NO. ABSOLUTELY DO NOT EVER TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HAILIANG WANG. YOU WILL SUFFER IMMENSELY.
Yes, its interesting, but not with this professor.
Yes. Although, be warned you will have to learn a LOT on your own if you take it with professor wang.
Yes. It sets a nice foundation of inorganic chemistry.

To be very honest, only take this course with Prof. Holland  the reviews of it seem to be much better than my experience with this professor. His teaching style made the course VERY challenging to learn, and the problem sets were basically all un-original problems that were still impossible to solve without going to peer tutor office hours. In addition to it being challenging, only a handful of students received As, though the rest of the grading wasn't too harsh on the lower end. The exams were pretty challenging with low averages, which made for a stressful environment.

Yes if they are interested in being a chemistry major or just understanding how the field is oriented. It is a decent option for an MB&B major taking another chem course, but O Chem II is probably more related. Otherwise, probably not.
Yes I would.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in inorganic chemistrythe content is very different from past chemistry classes you may have taken at Yale.

I would only recommend it if it is needed for a major, prerequisite, or they're really interested in inorganic chemistry. This isn't a course I'd recommend to my American Studies friends. The class is hard and doesn't need to be a pain if it's not needed.
